intro: Syncolostemon namapaensis, commonly known as the Namapa sandmat, is a flowering plant native to the arid regions of Namibia. It belongs to the Malvaceae family, which includes cotton and hibiscus, and is characterized by its hairy, glandular stems and leaves. The plant produces small, yellowish flowers that are clustered in dense inflorescences, often appearing in late summer. It is adapted to survive in dry, sandy soils and is often found in rocky habitats. Due to its limited distribution and specific ecological requirements, it is considered a rare and endangered species.
